Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: The city newsletter includes a short survey about bus routes open through next week.
Story: I was halfway through my lunch break when my phone buzzed with a message from my manager: “Can you confirm the meeting time with our external partner ASAP? They’re waiting.” As a colleague, I knew how important it was to respond quickly—leadership was counting on me to keep things moving smoothly. I opened my laptop, ready to reply, when I noticed the city newsletter in my inbox. The subject line caught my eye: “Help shape your bus routes—survey closes soon!” As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to participate, especially since I relied on those buses every day. The survey would only take a few minutes, but so would the email. I could feel the pressure mounting—my team needed me to be responsive, but my community needed my input, too. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between the urgent ping of my work and the quiet call of civic duty. I stared at the screen, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t do both at once.
